qas.question: What does Article 10 of the Berne Convention call certain uses that limit copyright?
Where are minimal quotations commonly used?
What categories do works that would normally be considered infringing fall into?

answers.text: principles underlying many earlier judicial precedents

qas.question: What are these statutes essential to?
What does Article 11 of the Berne Convention call certain uses that limit copyright?
What does Article 10 of the Berne Convention not call certain uses that limit copyright?
Where are maximum quotations commonly used?
What categories do work that wouldn't normally be considered infringing fall into?

plausible_answers.text: principles underlying many earlier judicial precedents

context: Article 10 of the Berne Convention mandates that national laws provide for limitations to copyright, so that copyright protection does not extend to certain kinds of uses that fall under what the treaty calls "<a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>fair practice<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>," including but not limited to minimal quotations used in <a1_0><b7_0>journalism and education<b7_0/><a1_0/>. The laws implementing these limitations and exceptions for uses that would otherwise be infringing broadly fall into the categories of either <a2_0><b8_0>fair use or fair dealing<b8_0/><a2_0/>. In common law systems, these fair practice statutes typically enshrine <a3_0><b9_0>principles underlying many earlier judicial precedents<b9_0/><a3_0/>, and are considered essential to <a4_0>freedom of speech<a4_0/>.
